title: How to Replace Dead Batteries in an Apple Magic Mouse

steps.title: Flip the mouse over.
steps.content: Flip the mouse over. The Magic Mouse's On/Off switch and battery compartment are both on the bottom of the mouse. If your Magic Mouse doesn't have a tab to remove the back cover and instead has a rectangular-shaped hole, you will not be able to remove the internal battery. This is a rechargeable Magic Mouse; to learn more, jump ahead to this section .

steps.title: Turn off the mouse.
steps.content: Turn off the mouse. To do so, slide the circular On/Off switch that's near the front of the mouse (on a green track) down. The green track should disappear when you do this.

steps.title: Push the black battery cover tab down.
steps.content: Push the black battery cover tab down. This tab is at the bottom of the mouse; sliding it down toward the rear end of the mouse will cause the cover to pop up. If the cover doesn't come up when you slide the tab down, use something thin (such as a guitar pick or a paper clip) to pry the cover up while holding down the tab. Be careful so you don't scratch the mouse.

steps.title: Pull the cover up and away from the mouse.
steps.content: Pull the cover up and away from the mouse. Doing so will remove the cover and reveal the two AA batteries inside. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the batteries.
steps.content: Remove the batteries. This is easiest to accomplish if you use your fingernails or a thin plastic object to pry each battery out by its front or back end. Never use a sharp metal object to remove batteries, as doing so will risk puncturing a battery or harming the mouse's internal components.

steps.title: Place two new AA batteries in the mouse.
steps.content: Place two new AA batteries in the mouse. Both batteries will have the "+" ends facing the front of the mouse and the "-" ends toward the rear of the mouse.

steps.title: Place the battery cover back on the mouse.
steps.content: Place the battery cover back on the mouse. You'll need to make sure that the slot for the black tab is aligned with the black tab at the bottom of the mouse.

steps.title: Push gently on bottom of the cover.
steps.content: Push gently on bottom of the cover. This will snap the cover back into place.

steps.title: Slide the On/Off switch up.
steps.content: Slide the On/Off switch up. Doing so will reveal a green track, and a small light in the top-right corner of the mouse's underside should come on, signifying that your mouse is on. Once the mouse connects to your Mac, you'll be able to start using it again. You may want to keep an eye on your mouse's battery life to ensure that your mouse doesn't die at a bad time.

steps.title: Flip your Magic Mouse 2 or 3 over.
steps.content: Flip your Magic Mouse 2 or 3 over. While you can't remove the Magic Mouse 2 or 3's battery, you can recharge it when its battery is low.

steps.title: Locate the Lightning charging port.
steps.content: Locate the Lightning charging port. This port is toward the bottom of the mouse's underside. It's a small, thin, rectangular hole. Your mouse should have come with its own charger, though you can use any Lightning charger to charge it.

steps.title: Plug your Lightning charger into a power source.
steps.content: Plug your Lightning charger into a power source. The wall socket side of the charger cable's power adapter, which resembles a white cube, has two prongs that should fit into the wall like any other standard plug. If you want to charge your mouse using your computer, gently tug the cable away from the power adapter and then plug the USB end of the cable (the end which was attached to the adapter) into one of your computer's USB ports.

steps.title: Plug the small end of the charger cable into your mouse.
steps.content: Plug the small end of the charger cable into your mouse. This end goes into the Lightning charging port at the bottom of your mouse's underside. [2] X Research source It doesn't matter which side of the Lightning charger is facing up or down when you plug it into the mouse.

steps.title: Let the mouse charge for at least one hour, but ideally two.
steps.content: Let the mouse charge for at least one hour, but ideally two. Doing so will ensure that your mouse is fully charged by the time you take it off of the charger. Your mouse will likely charge faster if you plug the charger into a wall socket than if you use a USB slot. You may want to keep an eye on your mouse's battery life to ensure that your mouse doesn't die at a bad time.

steps.title: Make sure your mouse is connected to your Mac.
steps.content: Make sure your mouse is connected to your Mac. To do so, simply move the mouse around and look for a response from the cursor on your Mac's screen. If your mouse isn't connected, it may not be on. You can turn on your mouse by flipping it over and sliding the switch near the front of the mouse up so that it displays green.

steps.title: Click the Apple Menu icon.
steps.content: Click the Apple Menu icon. It's in the top-left corner of your Mac's screen. Doing so will prompt a drop-down menu.

steps.title: Click System Preferences/Settings.
steps.content: Click System Preferences/Settings . This option is near the top of the drop-down menu.

steps.title: Click Mouse.
steps.content: Click Mouse . It will be in the menu on the left side of the System Settings window. Or, if you're using an older version of macOS, you'll see this option in the second row of options in the System Preferences window.

steps.title: Look for the "Mouse battery level" value.
steps.content: Look for the "Mouse battery level" value. It's in the bottom-left corner of this window; you should see a battery icon here, with the percentage of your mouse's remaining battery life listed to the right of the battery icon.
